head.title: Song V.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 220-221.

body.note: Tune. My Nanny O.22 The air (“My nanie, O”) had been published in Orpheus Caledonius (1725), no. 387; McGibbon (1742), no. 27; Caledonian Pocket Companion, 5 (1753), song 3; Bremner, Poetical Essays (1757), II:17. Johnson included the tune, with words by Allan Ramsay, in Scots Musical Museum, I (1787), song 88. Well before that Burns had used the tune for one of his earliest songs, beginning “Behind yon hills where Lugar flows;” the air is given in Thomson, Select Collection of Original Scotish Airs, IV (1793), song 4; and subsequently in Johnson, Scots Musical Museum, 6 (1803), song 580; see also Kinsley, I: 7 (item 4); Donald Low, ed., The Songs of Robert Burns (London: Routledge, 1993), pp. 50-52.

lg.l: The fop may praise the city belle,
In verse that charms the fancy O,
Wi’ simple croon I’ll please mysel’,

And praise my bonny Nancy O:33 Perhaps a reference to the popular song, “O Nancy wilt that go with me,” Scotticized variants of which were reprinted in several collections, e.g., “O Betsey” and “O Annie.” Burns describes “O Nancy” as “perhaps, the most beautiful Ballad in the English language” (Ferguson 1931:2.126).
Wha, without dress, and foreign aid,
Which at the first alarm ye O,
In hamely russet weeds array’d,
Like magic art can charm ye O.
Sic native dignity and grace,
Bot other arts, invite ye O,
Sic modest looks adorn her face,
And gentle smiles delight ye O;
Her blushing cheeks the crimson scorn,
Her een sae clear and glancy O,
The rose refresh’d wi’ dews of morn,
Is nought compar’d wi’ Nancy O.
Then cease to muse ye witless beaux,
Nae mair torment the fancy O;
But join wi’ me, and sing wi’ glee,
The praise of lovely Nancy O.
